name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament interrupted on Thursday 18 December 2014.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Colleagues Philippe Braham, Franck Brinsolaro, Frédéric Boisseau, Jean Cabut, Elsa Cayat, Stéphane Charbonnier, Yohan Cohen, Yohav Hattab, Philippe Honoré, Clarissa Jean-Philippe, Bernard Maris, 'Ten-seven people have died. These cartoonists, these journalists, these policemen, these simple employees, these ordinary citizens of the Jewish faith died because they defended and because they embodied what fanatics do not want to see: criticism, humour, satire, freedom of expression, our "living together" beyond opinions and confessions, our right to live together and in safety, our freedom simply.  Today, we must fear that journalists and cartoonists will censor themselves, that the irreverence of pencils will be silent in the face of gun violence. We must again fear that French Jews will feel threatened at home in France and Europe. We must fear that every Muslim is suspected, by irresponsible amalgamation. We must fear that the fear of the other will be stirred to destabilize our society. We must fear it because, if this happens, the terrorists will have won and we will have lost freedom. "Dear colleagues, we, the representatives of Parliament, also embody all that these fanatics hate: the peaceful collaboration between men and women that sometimes separates everything. Together, we must fight never to be contaminated by the hatred of terrorists. We must defend the freedom of all in Europe and the world. That is why we will also pay tribute today to the many victims of Boko Haram fanatics in Nigeria. This is a moment of great sadness, but we must act with caution.  Let me quote former Norwegian Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg, who said after the Oslo bombings in Utoya: "We will respond to terror with more democracy, more openness and tolerance". Let these words guide our work in this House. I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to stand up for a minute's silence in memory of the victims. Thank you very much.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I want to thank you, and thank all our colleagues who participated with us yesterday in Paris - Boulevard Voltaire - in this immense peaceful march for freedom. Everywhere else, across Europe, millions of people have made it a tremendous popular tsunami.  That is why 11 January will remain the birth date of the Europe of peoples united in diversity, united in adversity, united for our values and against hatred. United not in books, not in treaties and not even in speeches, but in the streets and in hearts. Because the victims of Paris are the same as those who fell in Madrid, London, Oslo, Brussels or Toulouse. You said it, Mr President: journalists killed because they were journalists, policemen killed because they were policemen, Jews killed because they were Jews, Muslims killed because they had read in the Koran that peace is the most beautiful of the names of God and comedians killed because they dared to laugh. The real targets are our universal values, which Europe proclaimed first and around which the whole European project is based: freedom of expression, freedom of belief, tolerance, the right to all differences, the dignity of the human person and, of course, the value of peace - the supreme value. Peace as a goal, as a means of resolving all disputes while preserving all differences. This is the miracle that Europe has achieved. This miracle is under threat. Already hatred had come back insidiously in speeches, it now returns in deeds.  It is up to us to be worthy of this formidable cry of brotherhood, which was taken yesterday in immense silence by all the crowds in Europe. (Applause)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr. President, in the name of what unites us, in the name of what we defend and will continue to defend, in the name of the fundamental rights of all women and men, in the name of their freedom to think, say, believe or not to believe, love and laugh , on behalf of my country, France, on behalf of all the countries of the European Union and the whole world that saw human beings fall because they were in the wrong place, at the wrong time, because they believed in another beyond or not, because their job was to protect us or because they were in the eyes of cowardly murderers the flag-bearers of our values I affirm with the millions of citizens who have stood up in Paris, france, in the cities and villages of the whole world, yesterday and the days preceding, that we will never give in.  Because Europe was built on the rejection of horrors committed in other times. Because terror must respond to more democracy and more rule of law. Because diversity is fruitful when tolerance and solidarity are its standard-bearers. Because like here, today, when a misfortune strikes one of their own, the others are in unison. We will not let anyone divide us, either in the Union or in our nations. Yes, we're all Charlie. That Charlie so Gallic, satirical always, so free. They fell with others under bullets that no god ever sponsored. But their ideals will remain alive because they make our raison d'être together: the rejection of fear, that of the other, of hatred, of barbarism.  The ideal that the victims of terrorists cherished is ours: democracy. Let us be proud of it, defend it and award an exceptional Sakharov Prize to Charlie Hebdo. (Applause)

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. In recent days, we in Europe and around the world have watched with great dismay and sadness at the threat to our European values of democracy, diversity, freedom and tolerance and how we, citizens, and our security were under attack. These senseless and repugnant acts of violence and murder go beyond our comprehension and our minds. But out of the darkness that surrounded us over the past week, what unites us emerged stronger than ever: our values. European citizens have made their voices heard en masse, a voice that says: "We stand for freedom, we stand for tolerance, we stand together." This week has shown Europe and the world that, whatever happens, our values remain unchanged. We believe in the freedom to experience religion, the freedom to think and say what we want, but especially in a society free from fear. The tragedies and suffering in France must strengthen our resolve. We must not fight among y's or point the finger at each other. The challenge is not only to ensure our safety, but also to connect our society. Only together can we come out stronger. In addition, no one is more or less because he or she has a different background. For us, it is not the past, but the future that matters. And that will be a future based on fundamental European values and freedoms. We all share in the pain of France and offer our deepest expression of sympathy. Unfortunately, words cannot help to reduce the grief, but we can promise today that, when its values are threatened, Europe will remain strong, free and united and will show decisiveness.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that terrorism has been killed in Europe, but never has an attack caused such a shock, as demonstrated by yesterday's demonstration in Paris where Mahmoud Abbas and Benjamin Netanyahu were seen side by side. A symbol of freedom of expression, the primary value of our democracy, has been targeted, and if we are all Charlie here in this Chamber, it is first of all because we are all Europeans and committed to the secular system of the rule of law that we have built. Let us not forget that among the three policemen murdered were a black woman, a Muslim and a native Frenchman. This proves that our societies are multicultural and that our rule of law is intended to give everyone a chance. Yet, from Madrid to London, and today to Paris, we must also acknowledge a failure. These terrorists are our children, born, raised and dead on our soil. Of course, the sectarian confinement that afflicts part of the youth and the jihadist indoctrination of some is a phenomenon that affects the entire Muslim world, but it also raises the question of our European role and responsibility.  For far too long, Europe has believed that it can turn away from the world's problems. Entry into Iraq and indifference to Syria are sources of terrorism. They have a huge impact on our daily lives and together we must create an ability to act in our neighbourhood instead of, Mr President, to confuse Islam and Islamism, this theocratic ideology. Islam has as much place in our societies as Christianity, Judaism or any religion or philosophy, and the vastness of the crowds of all origins who have demonstrated in recent days is living and vibrant proof of this.  Finally, we will need to take further action against terrorism at European level. This response cannot take the form of a limitation of civil liberties, but must be used to preserve them. Restricting these freedoms is precisely the aim of terrorists. Perhaps there is something positive about this whole tragedy, ladies and gentlemen. Last week, for me, another Europe was born for the first time: the Europe of peoples, the Europe of citizens and above all the Europe of values.  (Applause)

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Minister, we welcome the powerful outpouring of solidarity of the peoples of Europe and around the world with the french people in mourning, but standing and determined in the face of the executions of journalists, many of my personal friends, police officers and Jewish citizens. Yesterday, in every city and village, the people of France, united, came together to build a front, a solid roadblock against fundamentalist fundamentalism, against barbarism. And he did so with the knowledge that elsewhere in the world, from Baghdad to Kabul, from Aleppo to Kobane, the same terror floods the streets with blood. Those who were murdered were murdered for what they represented. Some the Jewish religion, the police the public service of the French Republic, and our journalist friends because they represented the free spirit and slinger, the refusal of the spirit of barracks.  In keeping with the ideals of these executed friends, we must avoid any political recovery and think about working more on ways to avoid this, on effective ways to eradicate terrorism. Clearly, the spirit of war does not allow it. What is the record of fifteen years of war on terror? We must do it differently and carry out a plan of co-development, of dialogue with the peoples of the Near and Middle East. The refusal to grant the Palestinian national movement for so long has only cast salt on the wounds of humiliation. The debate will certainly also arise between the dialectic of freedom and that of security. Security cannot be sacrificed on the altar of freedom. Freedom cannot be sacrificed on the altar of security. Both must live and progress together. We have a responsibility to build new bridges with the Mediterranean for a new type of dialogue and cooperation while drying up the financing of terrorist networks.  Finally, we cannot leave, as is the case today, so many abandoned neighbourhoods, children, teenagers suffering, young people with no future. That is why we need to move away from austerity choices to provide financial resources to school, culture, sport, training, early childhood, employment and aid to cities.  This must make us think at the same time. It is essential to get out of the amalgamations, the discourse of division and hatred that has been spreading for months. On the contrary, it is the spirit of popular unity that must take precedence, the spirit of the debate, the rejection of exclusion in order to make a common society, a common Europe. France said yesterday its spirit of brotherhood, of living together against barbarism, let us be worthy! (Applause)

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my thoughts are with the seventeen victims, artists and journalists defending freedom of expression, police officers, Jews, Christians, atheists and Muslims, as well as their families and loved ones. My thoughts are with the millions of citizens in France, Europe and the world who have expressed their sorrow and support, and who reminded us again yesterday that the camp of fear and hatred has not won.  However, in the aftermath of these attacks, when this huge shock in France and Europe was awakened, we still have to be careful not to fall into a double trap. The trap of the fanatics behind these terrible attacks, but also the trap of demagogues of all stripes who consider the events of recent days as a declaration of war of Islam to the rest of the planet. Just as we will not accept a war of civilization, we will not accept the nauseating amalgamations practised by identity and nationalist movements across Europe.  Another trap is also to be seen to see our civil liberties drowned out under a new security arsenal under the pretext of fighting terrorism. Remember the response of the United States after 9/11: the Patriotic Act led to many abuses that endangered the rights and freedoms of citizens as far as Europe, such as the CIA prison scandal and secret flights. Let's not fall into this trap. We do not protect human rights by denying them, we do not protect freedom with less freedom, as Mr Schulz said.  Let us act against the stigma and discrimination of children in Europe on the basis of their religion, name, origin or neighbourhood. Let us stop this spiral where the announced failure of our youth turns for all into despair and for some into hatred and barbarism. Since we are preparing a European investment plan, let us take advantage of it to give priority to education, training and public service for these millions of young people, to give Europe's children more love and less hatred, as a recent cover of the Charlie Hebdo magazine illustrated. (Applause)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I join with you and others in utterly condemning what has happened and in sympathising with the families and friends of those affected. It was quite something to see millions of people on the streets of Paris and elsewhere – sincere, worried, and, in some cases, very frightened people. However, there were also 40 significant, important political leaders, and they too were using the language of unity and solidarity; but I am afraid, for them, ‘Je suis Charlie’ is simply not enough, because we need now to have an honest admission that, actually, our political decisions have led to much of what has happened. Just think about foreign policy: from Afghanistan, through Iraq to Libya, and even the attempt to seek to arm the rebels in Syria. We were told that all of this was done to make our streets safer. In fact, what we have done is to stir up very deep resentment within much of the Muslim community, and it has had the very opposite of the desired effect. We have pursued policies of mass immigration at a rate that has made it frankly impossible for many new communities to integrate. For that, I think, we have to hold our hands up. Perhaps worst of all, we have been guilty of weakness, of lack of courage and of a lack of assertion in who we are as people, and we have turned a blind eye within many of our minority communities to practices that would not be tolerated in the rest of the population. Indeed, we have allowed preachers of hate to go around saying things that are totally unacceptable. The result of all this is that we have, I am sad to say, a fifth column that is living within our own countries and is utterly opposed to our values. How we deal with that problem is vital for the future. We must embrace the vast majority of Muslims, who themselves are horrified at the civil war that is going on within Islam. But unless we are prepared to admit our own culpability in much of what has happened, we are not going to be able to find solutions. I would suggest for the future, however, that we are going to have to be a lot braver and a lot more courageous in standing up for our Judeo-Christian culture. (Applause from the right)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking the brotherly peoples of Europe who have felt in communion with the French people for the past five days and have paid tribute with us to all these destroyed lives.  I think the first duty we have to the victims is to put a name to what killed them. It was not terrorism that killed them. Terrorism is a means. It was Islamist fundamentalism that killed them. It is this deadly ideology that has claimed so many lives and so many misfortunes over the past five days, but which is making so many in the world by the thousands today, just as we are talking.  Our societies, our countries are under attack because our values are shamed by fundamentalists. We have to face it, too. Our values, the first of which is obviously freedom. Mr. Mezri Haddad, former Tunisian ambassador to Unesco, denounced in a forum a few days ago, thirty years ago, of laxity, of angelism, of conformism, written by concessions to the proponents of identity Islam, holistic and totalitarian, in the name of republican democracy and tolerance. He called for self-criticism. That is what we have to do, self-criticism. Is Europe capable of protecting us, the European peoples, from the threat of Islamist fundamentalism? Can the full opening of our national borders be a means of controlling fundamentalists who cross borders one way or the other? Aren't the economic policies of austerity the ones that have collapsed our response capabilities and disarmed our police, intelligence and military? Those are all the questions we will have to ask ourselves.  As far as I am concerned, my religion is made: let the nations defend themselves! (Applause on the right)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda of this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 8 December 2015 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: Monday/Tuesday: No amendment Wednesday: the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance requests that a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative on the latest atrocities in northern Nigeria be put on the agenda. The debate is to be concluded with a resolution.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr President, as you have mentioned, our group proposes that we have a statement by the High Representative, preferably with a resolution, on the amazing, incredible, horrendous atrocities that have been conducted by the terrorist Islamist group, Boko Haram, in northern Nigeria. A whole town with its 2 000 people seems to have been wiped out, and this seems to be the most extensive and horrendous atrocity that this group has so far perpetrated. So I would ask that this House agree that we have it on our agenda on Wednesday.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, my group would like to support the fact that there is a statement by the High Representative and that we should have a debate on these events, which are already happening repeatedly in Nigeria and which are affecting the lives of many people and causing humiliation, especially women. In any case, we would prefer the Resolution to be adopted in the next plenary session, since we will discuss it at the end of this week and we will not have much time to prepare it, but we are in favour of debate and declaration. We do think it is important to address this issue and would prefer that the Resolution be on the agenda of the February part-session.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Does anyone want to speak out against it? That is not the case. Mrs Hautala, then I ask you: do you agree with Mr Guerrero's proposal that we first hear a statement and then make the resolution at the next part-session?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr President, I think this is a very good solution. I think it is our duty to discuss it this week.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr President, it is not to speak against, but just a question of whether we should have such an important debate on Wednesday or rather on Thursday morning, when probably more MEPs would be able to participate, rather than to have it late on Wednesday evening, given how the agenda looks at the moment.  So the proposal is to have it, but on Thursday in the morning.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We have actually already taken the vote. Incidentally, Mrs Mogherini is here on Wednesday, so I think it makes sense to hear the High Representative's statement on Wednesday.  We will try to put the item on the agenda in such a way that as many Members as possible can participate. Thursday: No change (the order of business is therefore adopted.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I have more sad messages to make to you.  On 19 December, our colleague Philip Bradbourn died at the age of 63 after a serious illness. Mr Bradbourn has been a Member of this House since 1999. He represented his region, the West Midlands, with great pride, he said. Philip Bradbourn began his political career after working as a city planner for more than 20 years. I have already expressed our sincere condolences to his friends on behalf of the European Parliament. I would like to do so again at this point. The European Parliament will not forget Mr Bradbourn. Leo Tindemans died at his home near Antwerp on 26 December last year at the age of 92. Deeply influenced by the brutal occupation of his homeland by the Nazis, who forced him to flee as a young man, as an eighteen-year-old, Tindemans worked tirelessly throughout his life for peace in Europe – as a member of the Belgian Parliament, as Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Belgium, as Foreign Minister of his country, and as a Member of the European Parliament. In the first direct elections to the European Parliament, Tindemans was elected in Belgium by such a majority that the newspapers even then named him "Mister Europa". I think Leo Tindemans was right to bear that name. He was certainly a great European. On behalf of the European Parliament, I offer my sincere condolences to his family. We will keep Leo Tindeman's honorable memory. I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to rise from your seats in honour of Philip Bradbourn and Leo Tindemans. (Members of Parliament rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on political importance (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, the directive on the secondment of workers is a very sensitive subject for workers and for business leaders, particularly in the construction and road transport sectors.  Every day, I am challenged by employers and citizens. Social dumping is a real scourge, on which the rejection of the European project is growing. It must be firmly fought. The enforcement directive should correct some of the weaknesses of the Detachment Directive. But there is an urgent need for its transposition into national legislation. It must be done in an ambitious way to ensure the rights of employees and to put an end to abuses, fraud and unfair competition. In this regard, national and European authorities must be able to draw on the experience and knowledge of the social partners. From now on, we need to consider the modalities of a partial revision of this directive.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for I would like to start with a terrible quote: "We do not want to see a significant minority of us with different cultural characteristics and backgrounds, we want to keep Hungary as Hungary." This terrible sentence was not said by a far-right politician, but by Hungary prime minister, Viktor Orban, following yesterday's Republican March in Paris. These are shameful, exclusionary and racist words. It also offends the memory of the victims of terror, the French and Europe, when the Prime Minister talks about immigrants as the cause of all evil. Orban has once again proved that he has no place among European leaders. I took part in the March in Paris myself and saw that this march was not about exclusion, but about belonging and strengthening the European spirit. Therefore, we must also make it clear here in the European Parliament: Viktor Orban, the Hungarian Prime Minister, did not speak for the Hungarians, we Hungarians are not like that! Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité – that's what we continue to say!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Madam President, against the background of the events of Paris, in which real Islamic terror over European values took place, I am extremely disturbed by the news and the assumption that large numbers of illegal immigrants who are on the territory of European countries will be sent back to Bulgaria. The situation currently requires exceptional European solidarity, requires a serious conversation on the subject of illegal immigrants and requires decisions to be taken at pan-European level, in the spirit of common European responsibility and common European solidarity. Bulgaria cannot afford to withstand on its territory a huge group of illegal immigrants of unproven origin and who have not received the relevant refugee status.  The current situation in the European Union requires the establishment of a common security policy and imposes a common conduct that ensures both our security and the preservation of our rights and values.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, in Venezuela there is political persecution, censorship of the media and the internet, arbitrary detentions, illegal imprisonment, torture and murder and systematic harassment of the opposition. This is not an opinion. It is the oprobious reality that the facts demonstrate. Countries such as Belgium have acknowledged this political persecution by granting emergency asylum to persecuted. Leopoldo López, the opponent, has been in jail illegally for months.  This Parliament has just spoken out mostly condemning this situation, but it troubles me and baffles me that 109 MEPs have refused to condemn it. I would like to say at the moment, and I would like to acknowledge, that the majority of this Parliament, 75%, not only condemnation, but will do what needs to be done to ensure that the Venezuelan Government assumes the responsibilities that human rights must assume and recovers for its citizens.  I want to say here that, just as images of people who are supposed to have been... are taught, forgiveness. Geraldine Moreno, I'm sorry, this is for you and this is for Rosa Orozco, who is your mother: "The resilient are also here in Parliament. I'm sorry, but we're going to hold out and I promise we're going to do what we have to do."

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, on 6 January 2015 Turkey, continuing its illegal actions, adopted a new directive

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 15 January last year the European Medicines Agency gave great news to hepatitis C sufferers: the new drugs, effective in 90% of cases, had passed controls and were authorised. But this immense joy for patients who until then were sentenced cannot be shared in the Spanish state, because the Government has restricted its use to a few cases – six or seven thousand – while doctors say that at least thirty thousand sick people need it. The sick look helpless. Twelve affected people die every day. They have had to lock themselves up in hospitals in Madrid or Girona, and they are still waiting for an answer. As they say, the Spanish government saves banks and cuts lives. The key to this conflict is submission to large pharmaceutical companies, which impose their prices: profits above people's lives. And if the European Commission supports them while their citizens die because of this irresponsible attitude, it becomes its accomplice.

name: Tim AKER
text: Madam President, we are told that we must stay in the EU because of jobs. Well, tell that to 220 of my constituents who lost their jobs when Tilbury power station closed in 2013. The Large Combustion Plant Directive has forced the closure of the plants in the UK that provide us with a third of our energy. All of this was done while Ed Miliband was Secretary of State at the Department of Energy and Climate Change. My residents in Thurrock need to ask Mr Miliband and his candidate in Thurrock, who worked for him at the time, why they did nothing to save those jobs. Together you have cost jobs in my community. The days of Labour looking out for working people in my constituency and my country are long gone. You have forgotten about communities like Tilbury and the people of Thurrock. In May you will be judged by your actions, because UKIP is standing up for working people in the United Kingdom.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: The construction of the South Stream gas pipeline would provide an alternative to Ukraine for several European countries, thus increasing security of supply. However, the Union's liberal, bureaucratic competition rules prevent this. I would add that, in the case of Nord Stream, which supplies Germany alone, this is not a problem. The U.S. Embassy in Budapest stated - an absolute statement - that the construction of South Stream threatens the Hungary energy independence. The reason is clear why you say it. It is in their interest that the transit country for Russian gas supplies should remain only Ukraine, whose government serves their interests. The European Union must decide whose interests it serves. In a global power game, will the United States be a hench member, or will it serve the interests of the member countries, the European population?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, as a person who advocates the rule of law, I ask the European Commission to condition on Serbia the abolition of amendments to the Law on the Organisation and Competence of State Organs in the War Crimes Procedure, which entered into force in 2010.  Otherwise, Serbia will not be able to continue its European path, which it began because it threatens the sovereignty of the Republic of Croatia and its citizens. Namely, Serbia has taken the right to try a Croatian citizen for an alleged crime committed on Croatian territory against another Croatian citizen, which is contrary to international criminal law and European practice. The fact that Croatian defender Veljko Maric, who was imprisoned by Serbian authorities and then issued an international warrant and has been held in prison for 5 years, is also how absurd this law is.  Therefore, I expect the European Commission to immediately ask Serbia to repeal this law and also to transfer Veljko Maric to Croatia and be given a fair trial.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I want to inform colleagues that we have adopted here in the Czech Republic, and these days the amendment to the Public Procurement Act, which transposes a large part of the public procurement directive adopted by this Parliament in 2014, is becoming effective. It is clear from the expert debate that we have had here in the Czech Republic that it is good if, at European level, we are able to agree on the fundamental principles of law governing public procurement. Entrepreneurs who want to compete not only in their national states, but, say, throughout Europe, can predict what rules of public tender they will regulate, and if those rules are similar, then I believe that this creates space for entrepreneurs, whether they are medium-sized entrepreneurs, smaller entrepreneurs or larger entrepreneurs, for better business and also better employment. So I welcome this directive, and I believe that in the future we should monitor how this directive will be applied and, where appropriate, consider further extension of the areas of public procurement law that should be regulated together.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: Madam President, I want to raise in the Chamber this evening the appalling crime of human trafficking and, in particular, the distressing subject of child trafficking. Human trafficking is the fastest growing criminal industry in the world; it is the second largest source of illegal income worldwide, 1.2 million people are trafficked every year globally, and it is estimated that 27 to 35 million people worldwide are trapped in a life of slavery. That is just short of the entire population of Poland. I want to commend the work of Tearfund with their ‘No child taken’ campaign, which tackles this issue head on. By focusing on 50 000 of the most vulnerable children, helping through education and vocational training and equipping them with skills which can lift them out of poverty, it is hoped that this will help keep those children safe from trafficking. In conclusion, a child is trafficked every 30 seconds. In the time I have been speaking tonight, two children will have fallen prey to traffickers. We have to work together to tackle this appalling crime and to ensure that children are protected across the world.

name: Alfred SANT
text: Fl-aħħar snin bnejna struttura qawwija ta' ħarsien għaż-żona euro. Hi qed titħaddem permezz ta' batterija sħiħa ta' għodod maħsuba biex ikejlu s-saħħa economics in finanzjarja tal-pajjiżi membri in jżomm r-riżultati ekonomièi in finanzing tagħhom fil-parameters mixtieqa. Dan jagħti l-impressjoni you qed nikkontrollaw is-sitwazzjoni aħjar. Għaliex, mela, żvilupp li subpost jitqies bħala relattivament èkejken għaż-żona, bħall-elezzjoni fil-Greèja, iqajjem inkwiet kbir?  Il-proġett tal-euro huwa wieħed politics; appuntu għalhekk sar importanti wisq biex jitħalla jfalli. Din tibqa' l-aqwa saħħa tiegħu l-aqwa dgħufija. Il-proġett inbena fuq il-bażi tas-soft power enormi li tgawdi minnu l-Unjoni Ewropea. Imma mill-bidu nett iż-żona euro ma kinitx żona monetarja ottimali. Ma kellhiex l-istrutturi federali meħtieġa biex iżommuha soda in d-diverġenzi economics fi ħdanha żdiedu mas-snin. It-tħaddim ta' pożittiviżmu tekniku biex nikkontrollaw is-sitwazzjoni qed jispièèa eżerèizzju ta' fetièiżmu policy li qed jherri l-istess soft power tal-Unjoni. Ħafna the mil-linji gwida taż-żona euro jitilqu minn if għadda żmienhom imma imma jiġġeddu b'mod policy in mhux teknik.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President! I am talking about an experience in my Brussels office that I probably share with many of you. With concentrated tension in front of my computer, I am ripped out of my work: the light goes out, I jump up, want to go to the switch and stumble over the pulled out drawer of my desk. As if by magic, the light goes on again. After half an hour the same game. Now I understand that an invisible motion detector is installed in my Office for Members. He should probably check whether there is still someone in the room or if it has been forgotten to extinguish the light. I don't know if that really saves electricity. But perhaps the deeper meaning is that we have to move, get up and row with our hands to signal that we are there. If that is what we want, Madam President, for us to do sports in our Member's office in the evening, then I would suggest that we reduce the rhythm from half an hour to a quarter of an hour so that we can do more evening sports.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Starbatty, we will examine this proposal. But you can also move in this building differently by moving quickly from one office to the next. That would be a different option.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: Madam President, colleagues, I am facing this authoritative hall on days when our European Union is under the shaking influence of the brutal terrorist attack in Paris. An act that was condemned by the chairman of Bulgaria's largest Liberal Party, Mr. Lyuthvi Meston, with the assessment that any civilisational difference is not only a cause for terrorism, but a reason for an even more convinced common aspiration for colorful and multiculturalism.  Against this background, I present to you the development of an anachronistic problem of intolerance in the Republic of Bulgaria. I say the development because I already had the opportunity to mark it during the plenary session on 12 November 2014. My violation is that during the last election campaign, alongside the official Bulgarian language, I also used several sentences in my mother tongue.  I objected to the competent Bulgarian authorities, I object here to you. The administrative act served on me is a gross breach of Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, Article 9 of the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities and Articles 11 and 22 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  Madam President, coming to an end, I am raising this issue not because I do not love my country, but because I also want it to reach the high democratic standards of a united Europe.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Madam President, in order to force the Irish people to pay 43% of the European banking crisis, Dublin governments have introduced several new stealth charges and taxes that have caused devastation and hardship to many families. These taxes have not led to improved services; they have been unfair and have deliberately targeted those on lower incomes disproportionately. The Irish people are sending a very clear message that they have had enough. In their hundreds of thousands, Irish communities have joined together and marched against the latest tax on their families. The Irish Government has called it a water charge, but the Irish people see it for what it is: another tax which, if introduced, would put many families over the edge and would further hamper domestic economies. That under pressure the Irish Government has now introduced temporary caps proves that the charge has absolutely nothing to do with water conservation but is just another attack on Irish families. I want to take this opportunity to declare in the European Parliament, as it has been declared on streets in every town in Ireland, that the water tax will be defeated and a new economic policy that is based on fairness and prosperity and against the austerity agenda will emerge.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday in Paris and across Europe and even around the world, there were millions of us saying: "We are not afraid. We are here to defend our values against the attack on this freedom of expression, against this living together." We say: we want to stay together. This will is a chance. After the fear we experienced, yesterday we experienced unity in diversity and demonstrated the desire to continue the adventure together. More than ever, let us build together Europe, an inclusive Europe in which everyone has a place, a Europe in which no one can be threatened because he is a journalist, because he is Jewish, because he is a Muslim, a policeman or a migrant.  Some are afraid of amalgams, others are afraid for their safety. This fear is understandable in view of the last days, but we must say to them loud and clear: "We are all together. Don't be afraid. We need everyone to build the future of our society." And I end by quoting a Mexican proverb: "They wanted to bury us; they didn't know we were seeds, seeds of freedom, seeds of democracy." So let's take responsibility.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I would like to draw attention here to a danger that is about to hang over a small island in the middle of the Mediterranean, rich in rare animal and plant species: Sardinia. In fact, Sardinia could soon be filled with radioactive waste.  Having imposed on us the military bases and their pollution of lead dust and uranium, there could now also be nuclear waste. A few days after the material is sorted, the government keeps everyone in the dark about where, how and how much waste to store. The time has come for someone, Europe first, to take action and averted the terrible fate that this island could face: that of becoming europe's first toxic garbage dump. That is why, today, in this House, I formally call on the Commission to ensure that it watches and intervenes before it is too late!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, Europe is experiencing unprecedented situations of violence. I like to think that we all condemn violence and terrorism wherever it comes from. In Greece, unfortunately, only in words and not in deeds. Since the day of our election, the MEPs of the People's League – Golden Dawn have been receiving threatening messages. In a letter to the Minister of Citizen Protection and the Chief of the Hellenic Police we informed of the incident and asked for protective measures for both us and the local assistants working in our offices. Unfortunately, we have not received any response.  I complain that on December 24, 2014 strangers spray-painted threatening messages against our lives on the walls and at the entrance to our offices. The police just recorded the incident. On December 25, 2014, Christmas morning, at night, strangers placed an incendiary device at the entrance resulting in material damage to our offices. Both the country's political world and the media have ignored the fact.  We ask the European Parliament for its support in order for the Greek Government to act as it should and at last to be placed around the clock in our offices, so that our partners and we can take care of our work. Already the People's League–Golden Dawn mourns two victims of a terrorist attack on November 1, 2013. I hope we don't mourn any more victims and then in front of the cameras we say 'I'm Charlie too'.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, in Greece we have elections on 25 January 2015 and this gives the opportunity to various international media to bring back the issue of so-called Grexit, namely forced exit from the euro area. In fact, some international companies also give rates of 25%. I believe that if everyone - Greek and European colleagues - is consistent with our obligations, everything will be fine and I am also responding to the concerns of some who link Greece's problems with the euro. What are we supposed to do? Firstly, to be consistent with the obligations we have undertaken, and secondly, to restructure the debt, to make its repayment from thirty to fifty years, to drop the interest payments and thus to enable the economy to grow. If we are effective and fast, we will prevent negative developments in the economy and annihilate the chances of the so-called Grexit.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. You are known for your sensitivity to human rights. It must not be the case that one country in the European Union cares for a third-country national and grants him asylum, and then another Member State deportes the same person to his country of origin, where he is threatened with persecution. This is a violation of the principle of non-refoulment, which each Member State should respect. Today I am talking about a Citizen of Kazakhstan, Muratbek Ketebayev, who was granted political asylum in Poland and has now been detained and threatened with deportation from Spain to Kazakhstan.  Dear Colleagues, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. MEPs from Spain, I ask you not to allow political refugees to be sent back to countries where

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Madam President, in a new year, in Croatia there ceased to be a category of traditional small-scale fishing for personal purposes. Over ten thousand small fishermen have lost the right to ensure survival and stay alive on the islands through traditional methods. And life on the islands is already hampered enough by limited transport connections and higher costs. The sustainability of the fish stock as a goal is unquestionable. However, it is questionable how much fish stock stocks are at risk due to small fishermen and why, without relevant scientific research, small fishermen and this category of fishing are held accountable. Abuse of the rules has always been, but the solution is better control, not prohibition. While European legislation knows only the categories of sport and professional fishing, the December 2013 resolution on the Adriatic and Ionian Fisheries Strategy clearly mentions the diversity of fishing. Failures in eu membership negotiations must not be used as an alibi for attacks on small fishermen and our traditions. Traditional small-scale fishing is first and foremost a lifestyle, part of identity and a prerequisite for existence. That's why we have to do everything we can to protect him and preserve him.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe you spoke in Paris is consistent and make an extraordinary commitment to defending democratic freedoms and freedom of expression in order to help all countries in the throes of extremism. Let us not leave Africa alone! A few weeks ago, in this House, the Sakharov Prize was awarded to Dr Mukwege and a few days ago the accounts from the hospital he ran were frozen. Europe is showing a strong signal, in defence of freedoms and against any serious violation of human rights, as, in this case, in the Democratic Republic of Congo! The Europe that spoke in Paris does not leave Nigeria alone, where endless horror is unfolding at the hands of Boko Haram and I am delighted at the decision taken in this House today by Parliament to continue on this point. Further attacks, still dead, as a village in Cameroon has been attacked at the moment, and we must react to that. However, there is no lack of hope, embodied by a little girl who a few days ago showed the strength to oppose her tormentors by refusing to blow herself up, courageously, after the first explosion she handed herself in to the authorities, rebelling. Europe must be there, leading an international task force!

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to express my deep respect for the journalists and cartoonists who have been murdered in Paris for their service to our liberal society, for the policemen who have been murdered in the performance of their service to their country, and for other victims who have been murdered because they are part of our society, which these terrorists hate so much.  My sympathies go out to the families and friends of the victims. My concern, however, is for a Europe that at the moment prefers to blame each other for this incomprehensible crime than to stand united against a small but all the more radical minority and take decisive action against it. Because the common values seem to have been largely lost and it prefers to discuss what values these might be. What we need is a discussion about our common values and an assurance of our common values, so that this society is strong against those extremists who are terrorising us.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Madam President! After the tragic events in Paris, we feel deep sorrow, sadness and also fear. We are afraid of not knowing what the consequences of last week's events will be for our future lives. Once again, we have been painfully reminded that freedom and democracy are values that must be defended. A free society is a value for which it is worthwhile to stand up for it with all its strength, always and against all threats from all directions, because liberal democracy is a very sensitive plant that must be protected. The calls for the introduction of the death penalty, for the reintroduction of data retention or for a further tightening of immigration policy, as we are now hearing from the right political corner, are not only false responses to terrorist attacks, as the past has shown us, they are also a threat to the free society in which we live. What we need is more democracy, more freedom of expression and more rule of law. And we need the courage to defend them with the right means.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Madam President, I would like to draw attention to a situation that is unacceptable to Romania, which is being treated as a second-rate country. In 2007 we joined the European Union, in recognition of the efforts and progress made in most areas. However, entry into the Schengen area has been postponed in order to fulfil special technical security conditions. Today, Romania's borders fulfil all the technical conditions assumed, which is recognised by all those responsible, while being a provider of security and stability, both for the region and for the whole Union. However, unreasonably, we are denied access to the Schengen area under unacceptable pretexts for a Europe that is intended to be respectable. This creates unfair competition between Romanian and foreign firms, severely affecting the movement of goods and the lives of Romanian citizens.  That is why we must say this clearly and clearly: Romania must be treated equally with the other Member States of the European Union, it must enjoy all full rights, and accession to the Schengen area is not only a right of Romania, but also an obligation of the European Union!

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: In 2011, this House adopted the European Roma Strategy. Since then, national strategies have been born, reports have been made, paper has been born, but the situation has not substantially changed. Today, even within the European community, the Roma community faces serious discrimination in almost all aspects of daily life– housing, education, health. You have to plan your life in a way that you face constant discrimination. Nevertheless, I do not have the impression that the European Parliament or the European Commission is handling this situation according to its weight. To this day, I do not know who, which Commissioner within the European Commission, belongs to the area of dealing with the Roma. Although we are talking about european citizens as you, Madam President or I. I therefore urge Parliament and the European Commission to deal with the situation of the Roma in Europe much more effectively than before.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! It is not just politicians who make politics, a single word is enough, and such a word is Grexit. Grexit is being launched from German government circles, at least it is not denied from there. But Grexit is a word creation – nothing else – for deception and threat. The German electorate, which is about to accept the third Greek bailout, is to be deceived and the Greek electorate is to be threatened. For the Greek electorate should not elect Alexis Tsipras and his Syriza. This is massive interference in democratic elections in a democratic country. I think that is underground and undemocratic. The euro is not working, it is costing many millions of people the job and the future. But it is also increasingly costing us our democracy. It is not a currency that is the heart of Europe, it is democracy. Let's protect them!

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: Madam President, the cowardly terrorist attack in the Charlie Hebdo newsroom and the events of the following hours, resulting in 17 casualties, bereaved France and shocked an entire world. Yesterday's solidarity march in Paris, with more than one and a half million participants, showed that French citizens and European citizens do not intimidate against terror and are united for freedom of the press, tolerance, individual freedoms, peace and good coexistence. We must stand firm and united in the face of extremism, terrorism, religious intolerance, make every effort to strengthen institutions that fight terror and build common strategies as effective as possible to remove the deeper causes of these events.  All compassion and support for families, newsroom colleagues and all French citizens affected by the tragic events. I'm Charlie!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Madam President, it is clear from two talks given at the end of December by the President and the Chief Economist of the European Central Bank (ECB) that the risk of deflation exists for the euro area and we obviously know the dangers of this economic configuration: increased debt burden, lower demand and therefore consumption and in the end , rising unemployment.  Of course, the evolution of the price of petroleum products is, in this respect, favourable since it should restore some purchasing power to the citizens, but will this be enough to stem the deflationary risks? Indeed, once again, austerity policies are now demonstrating the full extent of their negative impact, both in human and social terms and on the economic front. A timid first step in reviving has been taken through the plan proposed by the President of the Commission, but I think that we clearly need to go far beyond that today. Two levers seem to me to be essential in this regard.  Firstly, productive public investment should be neutralised to boost the economy by changing the calculation of deficits, and therefore not just in the context of public participation in the European specific investment fund.  Secondly, the ECB must play a greater role in the European recovery, particularly in preventing the risk of deflation. As such, the TLTRO operation has shown the limits of the voluntaryness of private investment. It must therefore develop expansionary measures to promote public investment and thus leverage public leverage to boost demand and employment.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Madam President, I would like to denounce the situation of the families of the victims of Francoism in Spain. The principles set out by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights read as follows: "A people's knowledge of the history of their oppression belongs to their heritage and, as such, must be preserved with appropriate measures in the name of the State's duty to memory."  Especially painful and traumatic is the pain of the families of the victims of Francoism in Spain who have not yet been able to even give burial to their relatives by not having located them in one of the countless mass graves that still persist in my country.  The Socialist government passed a law that has been paralyzed by the current Government of the People's Party. The Government of the Junta de Andalucía has shown sensitivity and commitment to the victims of Francoism and will shortly pass a law for democratic memory in my region, Andalusia. In the face of all this, the current Government of my country's People's Party leaves national law without content and is allowing there to be no room for truth, justice and reparation for the victims of Francoism in Spain. Therefore, as a speaker of these demands, I would like to denounce this situation before this House.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes this item.
